The fact that such ridiculous claims are made is why I would not that distressed to see it go. Evolution is true but most supporters bend the truth to much.
chaoticgnome

Seeing as geology studies rocks, tectonics, and other such phenomena, and evolution is a theory discussing the development of biology, I can pretty much guarantee that geology is not dependant on evolution. Modern geology, however, is founded upon a model of earth billions of years old. It is founded upon this model because no other system can better explain the conditions we see in nature. Modern evolutionary theory also is based on a model that stretches back into the billions of years, and often people misconstrue this length as being integral to the theory. 
 
 As for "teaching subjects hard to teach yourself," that is a question of education policy and is moot on this forum. I can tell you; however, that removing evolution from our education would in essence destroy biology education. Evolution is a good model for predicting everything in biology from animal behavior to genetic drift; thus evolution is intimately entwined with modern biology.
 
 Your initial suggestion at the top of this forum is like saying except for a few rocket scientists; we don't need to bother teaching relativity. To remove relativity from physics sets the science back over one hundred years. We can't pick and choose what parts of science to teach, it has to be all or nothing. To say some aspect of science shouldn't be taught because it is religiously controversial, or too easy, or too complicated, destroys the entire concept of open inquiry in science. 
 
 In the modern scientific world, all doors are open so anyone can gain the necessary knowledge they need. Educating science should be the same.

OK lets see if I can communicate a simple concept. Forget everything else I said and lets start from the begining. This concept has nothing to do with the details of evolution itself and I would suggest people don't try and see the connection to evolution/creation debate until they understand the concept. Consider two highly hypothetical people Fred and Wilma. 
 
 Every time Fred merely points out that he eats chips only at christmas Wilma attacks Fred for proposing the ridiculous idea that "everyone should eat chips all the time". When Fred tries to clarify that he only eats chips and christmas Wilma replies that chips are very bad for you. Then Fred claims you can make occasional exception to the zero tolerance on chips policy and Wilma replies Fred is a idiot for not seeing the health horrors of force feeding everyone 20 bags of chips a day. 
 
 Now is this hard to understand? Is it a total mystery to how I connect my Fred and Wilma idea to the debate? Of course many analogies are plain bat5h!t insane but do me courtesy of explaining why they are insane.

 Our choice is to teach nothing, teach things that are both true and false intentionally, or intentionally try to teach what is true.
 
 I think morally we feel teaching what we can defend as true, and removing it when it's shown to be false, is the only honest way to approach this problem. Which is probably why it's approached this way.
 
 I have to say, of all the concepts I learned in biology, evolution is the single most important. Worse still, I know this is perhaps odd sounding, but I think about "evolution" with respect to a great many subjects, and a great many circumstances in my own life. Without someone telling me about it, I'd have to fumble around and perhaps discover it on my own (not from scratch, but the aha moment), or stay ignorant. "evolution" as a mechanism isn't really even a biological phenomnon in that respect, it's just part of how the universe "functions".
 
 If I found out you intentionally wanted me to remain ignorant...I would be angry...it's essentially intellectual oppression.
